channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: #159 - The Pittsburgh Perl Workshop 2014 Tilt Campaign
item.description:
Hi,

Greetings from Germany where I am currently teaching a 'Test automation using Perl' course.

Relax and enjoy the summer!

Or winter. If you happen to be on the other side of the globe.
item.dc:subject: list of tags?

item.title: ZipRecruiter is hiring modern Perl Programmers (Los Angeles or remote in US)
item.description: At ZipRecruiter, our goal is to build the best online services for finding and filling jobs. We've grown from 4 to over 100 employees in less than 4 years with zero funding. We care about code quality and quality of life. To learn more about our business and values, please follow the link above.

item.title: We are Hiring a Senior Perl Software Developer - Grant Street Group
item.description: We are a growing software company using open source software/modern Perl practices to build innovative e-payment, auction, and tax collection web applications. We are looking for talented, motivated professionals committed to flawless work and customer service.

item.title: The Pittsburgh Perl Workshop 2014 Tilt Campaign
item.description: Would you like to go to the Pittsburgh Perl Workshop? The organizers ask for your commitment before they start to organize. Go place your tilt for $125.

item.title: Kickstarting Mastering Perl Course at the Swiss Perl Workshop
item.description: brian d foy offers various options from getting an e-book version of the book 'Mastering Perl' through participating in his training class in ZÃ¼rich till having him consult for your for a full day.

item.title: How should conference speakers be compensated?
item.description: brian d foy explains how the Master Classes he started to run at YAPC::Chicago in 2006 helped financing some of the speakers. IMHO, as I also wrote already this is a win-win and such training classes can even help sponsoring other parts of the conference.

item.title: Mojolicious - Perl real-time web framework
item.description: A long thread of discussion on HackerNews that of course diverges to the discussion of OOP in Perl and sigils and whatnot.

item.title: Perl as a career option
item.description: Andrew Solomon has been interviewed by Linux Career covering quite a few topic from 'Modern Perl' via web development to 'how to get started with Perl'.

item.title: Rescue legacy code with modulinos
item.description: Modulino is a Perl module that can be also used as a script. brian d foy explains how this feature can be used to convert scripts into modules and make it easier to start testing them.

item.title: Check your test coverage with Devel::Cover
Parse Excel with ease using Perl
item.description: David Farrell shows how to read Excel files using Spreadsheet::Read.

item.title: Catalyst vs Dancer vs Mojolicious on Stack Overflow
item.description: I checked the number of posts on Stack Overflow tagged with each one of those: Catalyst: 380, Mojolicious: 213, Dancer: 133. Does this mean anything?

item.title: Catalyst 5.90070 has Landed!
Don't be afraid to rename your module / dist
item.description: Neil Bowers explains module name choices and how to rename a module.

item.title: Curating CPAN sometimes means really deleting stuff
item.description: Philippe Bruhat (BooK) shows 3 cases when he decide a module should be totally removed from CPAN and uses his examples to encourage others too to remove obsolete modules.

item.title: Fix a bug on CPAN Day
item.description: It is Neil Bowers again (I really hope he will create a post linking to all of his CPAN-day related posts) showing how the number of bugs on RT are steadily growing (but not even looking at bugs reported elsewhere). More importantly he created a list of the to 20 distributions in terms of open RT tickets. There are some very important modules in that list! Go ahead, you can fix a bug or at least write a test case.

item.title: Don't declare a dependency on Crypt::SSLeay (or IO::Socket::SSL either)
item.description: Instead of that, if your code uses https then declare a dependency on LWP::Protocol::https.

item.title: Fix your CPAN Testers failures on CPAN Day
item.description: Another thing you can do to help CPAN and the Perl ecosystem.

item.title: Taking CPAN With You
item.description: Michael Greb shows how to use CPAN::Mini to create a local copy of CPAN, and how to use it with cpanm, cpanp, or with good old cpan.

item.title: Maintaining Perl 5: Grant Report for Month 11
item.description: The monthly report from Tony Cook. (The unofficial list of grants and reports is here.)

item.title: Maintaining Perl 5: Grant Report for Month 12
GSoC Week 11: Improving Documentation for MetaCPAN.
item.description: Talina Shrotriya keeps herself busy with MetaCPAN activity heading towards the "Web of Trust" that will hopefully vastly improve the search results on MetaCPAN.

item.title: Maintaining the Perl 5 Core: Report for Month 10 (July 2014)
perlcc next steps
item.description: Compiling Perl code to executable? Some crazy optimizations done by Reini Urban at cPanel.

item.title: 2014.31 (for real this time)
item.description: The Perl 6 weekly.

item.title: (cxlv) stackoverflow perl report
(cxx) metacpan weekly report - Time::Moment
Don't interpolate in printf (Missing argument in sprintf at ...)
item.description: A screencast (and article) on how I made a stupid mistake and how you could avoid it.

item.title: Perl-related events
item.description: In the following cities: Sofia (Bulgaria), Tokyo (Japan), FlÃ¶rli Olten (Switzerland), Hancock (NY/USA), Itapema (SC/Brasil), Salzburg (Austria), Barcelona (Spain), London (UK)
